messageBody:
Hi Charlie,
Thanks - this comment and example is illuminating. But I have a followup
question. Again, I'm pretty new to java so this is a bit of a brain-teaser for
me.

In your example, I think you are assuming a class variable 'Connection' in the
MyTestSetup class, as follows:

class MyTestSetup extends TestSetup {
Connection connection;
public MyTestSetup( Test t ) {
super(t);
}

protected void setUp() {
connection = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:url");
}

protected void tearDown() {
}
}

So in the MyTest class there is a unit-test called 'testOne()'. To extend your
example, this unit-test needs a reference to the Connection instance saved in
the 'MyTestSetup' class. How does it get it? I am guessing that class
variables are also needed in the MyTest class just like in the MyTestSetup
class, and maybe the 'MyTest.setup' method needs to initialize the
MyTest.connection class variable before each test starts. But how does the
MyTest find a reference to the MyTestSetup instance?

thanks

--- In junit@egroups.com, "Stephen P Peterson"
<stephen.peterson@i...> wrote:
> What if the setup logic involves connecting to databases and
> running queries that tends to be a bit slow for doing on every
> single test? Is an explanation available anywhere on the web
> telling how to get tests to run faster by executing slow
> initialization code only once before all the tests?

Stephen,

What you want to do is create a class that extends TestSetup.
TestSetups allow you to do some initilization/de-initilization around
a test suite just as you described.

class MyTestSetup extends TestSetup {
public MyTestSetup( Test t ) {
super(t);
}

protected void setUp() {
Connection = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:url");
}

protected void tearDown() {
}
}

class MyTest extends TestCase {
public MyTest( String name ) {
super( name );
}

public void testOne() {
}

public static Test suite() {
return new MyTestSetup( new TestSuite( MyTest.class ) );
}

public static void main( String args[] ) {
TestRunner.run( suite() );
}
}
